div1.p: Major Gen George C. Strong, who was mortally wounded in that night attack on Wagner bears distinct dying in bed testimony to the black troops' courage. A lady who was with him in Hospital, after the attack, writing about his Gen. S's remarks on several topics, continues:

add.p: He said until then the Fifty-fourth Massachusetts had not been under fire, and he knew not how they would stand it; therefore he had ordered the Sixth Connecticut, if the Fifty-fourth should break, to rush right on for the fort. 'But,' said the general, 'they behaved nobly and fought bravely. Colored soldiers will stand fire, and fight well, too.'
